title: Estimated/Expected Peak Expiratory Flow (Peak Flow)
description: Estimates expected peak expiratory flow rate and quantifies asthma exacerbation severity based on age, height, race, and sex.

parameters.name: race_ethnicity
parameters.description: Patient race/ethnicity for appropriate formula selection

parameters.name: measured_pef
parameters.description: Measured peak expiratory flow (optional, for comparison and zone calculation)

result.name: peak_flow_results
result.description: Expected peak expiratory flow and zone assessment

ranges.interpretation: Peak flow in normal range. Continue current treatment plan.
Peak flow below normal. May indicate developing exacerbation. Consider increasing treatment.
Dangerously low peak flow. Severe asthma exacerbation. Seek immediate medical attention.

references: Hankinson JL, Odencrantz JR, Fedan KB. Spirometric reference values from a sample of the general U.S. population. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 1999 Jan;159(1):179-87. doi: 10.1164/ajrccm.159.1.9712108.
Nunn AJ, Gregg I. New regression equations for predicting peak expiratory flow in adults. BMJ. 1989 Apr 22;298(6680):1068-70. doi: 10.1136/bmj.298.6680.1068.
Godfrey S, Kamburoff PL, Nairn JR. Spirometry, lung volumes and airway resistance in normal children aged 5 to 18 years. Br J Dis Chest. 1970 Jan;64(1):15-24. doi: 10.1016/s0007-0971(70)80045-0.
Global Initiative for Asthma. Global Strategy for Asthma Management and Prevention, 2023. Available from: www.ginasthma.org
formula: Variable formulas based on age and ethnicity: Ages 5-7 and 8-17 non-Caucasian: PEFR = [(Height, cm - 100) × 5] + 100; Adults 18-80 non-Caucasian: Male PEFR = {[(Height, m × 5.48) + 1.58] - [Age × 0.041]} × 60, Female PEFR = {[(Height, m × 3.72) + 2.24] - [Age × 0.03]} × 60; Caucasian/African American/Mexican American: Hankinson 1999 NHANES III equations
notes: Formulas vary by age group and race/ethnicity
Height and sex are most strongly correlated with peak flow
Not a standalone diagnostic tool - must be combined with clinical assessment
Yellow zone: 50-79% of expected (caution, may need treatment adjustment)
Red zone: <50% of expected (emergency, seek immediate medical attention)
Peak flow variability >20% may suggest asthma diagnosis
Regular monitoring helps assess treatment effectiveness
Useful for patients without known baseline peak flow
Most accurate when compared to patient's personal best value
Environmental factors and technique can affect measurements
Consider diurnal variation in peak flow measurements
